qas.question: What view did Louis Agassiz have of On the Origin of Species?

answers.text: strongly opposed to the ideas in the book

qas.question: What view did some clergymen in the Church of England take of the theory of natural selection?

answers.text: interpreted natural selection as an instrument of God's design

qas.question: What did Darwin do to show that he admired the cleric Charles Kingsley?

answers.text: Darwin quoted Kingsley as "a celebrated cleric", and added the phrase "by the Creator" to the closing sentence,

qas.question: What did some commentators think about Darwin changing the phrasing in his book?

answers.text: some commentators have taken this as a concession to religion that Darwin later regretted

qas.question: What were Darwin's views on the part of God in his theory?

answers.text: Darwin's view at the time was of God creating life through the laws of nature

context: Natural theology was not a unified doctrine, and while some such as Louis Agassiz were <a0_0>strongly opposed to the ideas in the book<a0_0/>, others sought a reconciliation in which evolution was seen as purposeful. In the Church of England, some liberal clergymen <a1_0>interpreted natural selection as an instrument of God's design<a1_0/>, with the cleric Charles Kingsley seeing it as "just as noble a conception of Deity". In the second edition of January 1860, <a2_0>Darwin quoted Kingsley as "a celebrated cleric", and added the phrase "by the Creator" to the closing sentence,<a2_0/> which from then on read "life, with its several powers, having been originally breathed by the Creator into a few forms or into one". While <a3_0>some commentators have taken this as a concession to religion that Darwin later regretted<a3_0/>, <a4_0>Darwin's view at the time was of God creating life through the laws of nature<a4_0/>, and even in the first edition there are several references to "creation".
